sn35.1:1.1.comm: The “interior” aspects of the sense fields are the sensory organs starting with the “eye”, as opposed to the sense stimuli starting with “sights”, which are “exterior” (bāhira). | Ajjhatika/bāhira (“interior/exterior”) are used for the senses because they refer to inner and outer aspects of a thing, in this case, the individual. The similar pair ajjhatta/bahiddha (“internal/external” or “inside/outside”) indicates the relation of two things to each other (see SN 35.69:1.4). Thus a house may have its interior painted white and exterior painted blue (ajjhatika/bāhira), while a chair might be inside the house or outside of it (ajjhatta/bahiddha). This agrees with Vedic usage. For bahirdhā, Chāndogya Upaniṣad 3.12.7 mentions “what is outside a person”;  it’s also someone who is “outside” the sacrifice (eg. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.9.2.2). Bāhya is used in philosophical contexts, where it sometimes contrasts with ādhyātmika (Māṇḍūkya Upaniṣad Kārikā 2.38), but more commonly antara: “the body is exterior, the womb interior” (ŚB 6.6.2.16); “eyes are interior, ears exterior” (ŚB 13.4.4.8). Sages aspire to transcend this duality:  “As a man embraced by a woman he loves is oblivious to everything within or without, so this person embraced by the self consisting of knowledge is oblivious to everything within or without” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.21, Olivelle translation). See also note on SN 35.4:1.5.

sn35.1:1.2.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn35.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn35.1:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn35.1:2.1.comm: This section gives a series of basic teachings with systematic variations. These can be understood as meditation instructions. The various templates and their usage patterns are mapped in the concordances appended to Bhikkhu Bodhi’s Connected Discourses.

sn35.1:2.4.pli: Yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn35.1:2.4.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn35.1:2.9.comm: Right from this first discourse, the teachings on the six senses are highly abbreviated in the Pali. A standard pattern, which is used in the next several discourses, is to give the first and last items in full, while the middle ones are abbreviated. However, in this discourse, while the “ear” and “nose” have been abbreviated, the Pali gives the “tongue” in full, then abbreviates “body”, then tells the “mind” in full. This pattern recurs throughout this Saṅyutta (eg. SN 35.7:1.10, SN 35.13:1.15, SN 35.25:1.6). Often, the pattern is even more extreme, as the “ear” and “nose” and sometimes “body” are omitted entirely, while the “tongue” is given in full (SN 35.26:1.6, SN 35.27:1.4). This only applies to the interior “tongue”, not to the exterior “taste”. As to why this odd pattern appears, I think it is because “tongue” (jivhā) is the only term among the twelve that is feminine. Feminine declensions in Pali are quite different to masculine and neuter. Perhaps these passages are spelled out in full to ensure the correct forms are used. In any case, I do not attempt to represent this in my translation, but use the standard pattern.

sn35.1:2.12.pli: Yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.

sn35.1:2.18.pli: Yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn35.1:2.18.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn35.1:2.19.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati, sotasmimpi nibbindati, ghānasmimpi nibbindati, jivhāyapi nibbindati, kāyasmimpi nibbindati, manasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.1:2.19.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn35.1:2.20.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.1:2.20.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.1:2.21.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn35.1:2.21.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.10:0.3.eng: The Exterior as Impermanent in the Three Times

sn35.10:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, sights of the past and future are impermanent,

sn35.10:1.3.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītesu rūpesu anapekkho hoti;

sn35.10:1.5.pli: paccuppannānaṃ rūpānaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.

sn35.10:1.12.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītesu dhammesu anapekkho hoti;

sn35.10:1.14.pli: paccuppannānaṃ dhammānaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hotī”ti.

sn35.100:1.2.eng: A mendicant in retreat truly understands.

sn35.100:1.4.eng: They truly understand that the eye is impermanent.

sn35.100:1.8.pli: ‘yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn35.100:1.8.eng: the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is impermanent.

sn35.100:1.10.eng: A mendicant in retreat truly understands.”

sn35.101:1.2.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn35.101:1.2.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.101:1.4.eng: The eye isn’t yours: give it up.

sn35.101:1.6.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn35.101:1.6.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.101:1.9.pli: Te vo pahīnā hitāya sukhāya bhavissanti.

sn35.101:1.12.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.

sn35.101:1.15.pli: So vo pahīno hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.

sn35.101:1.16.pli: Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi na tumhākaṃ.
sn35.101:1.16.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact isn’t yours: give it up.

sn35.101:1.18.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn35.101:1.18.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.101:2.3.pli: Sā vo pahīnā hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.

sn35.101:2.6.pli: Te vo pahīnā hitāya sukhāya bhavissanti.

sn35.101:2.9.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.

sn35.101:2.12.pli: So vo pahīno hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.

sn35.101:2.13.pli: Yampidaṃ jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi na tumhākaṃ.

sn35.101:2.14.pli: Taṃ pajahatha. Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati …pe….

sn35.101:3.1.eng: The mind isn’t yours: give it up.

sn35.101:3.3.pli: So vo pahīno hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn35.101:3.3.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.101:3.6.pli: Te vo pahīnā hitāya sukhāya bhavissanti.

sn35.101:3.9.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.

sn35.101:3.12.pli: So vo pahīno hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.

sn35.101:3.13.pli: Yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi na tumhākaṃ.
sn35.101:3.13.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact isn’t yours: give it up.

sn35.101:3.15.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn35.101:3.15.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.101:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yaṃ imasmiṃ jetavane tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṃ taṃ jano hareyya vā ḍaheyya vā yathāpaccayaṃ vā kareyya,
sn35.101:4.1.eng: Suppose a person was to carry off the grass, sticks, branches, and leaves in this Jeta’s Grove, or burn them, or do what they want with them.

sn35.101:4.3.pli: ‘amhe jano harati vā ḍahati vā yathāpaccayaṃ vā karotī’”ti?
sn35.101:4.3.eng: ‘This person is carrying us off, burning us, or doing what they want with us’?”

sn35.101:7.1.pli: “Na hi no etaṃ, bhante, attā vā attaniyaṃ vā”ti.
sn35.101:7.1.eng: Because  to us that’s neither self nor belonging to self.”

sn35.101:8.1.eng: “In the same way, the eye isn’t yours: give it up.

sn35.101:8.3.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn35.101:8.3.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness. …

sn35.101:8.7.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi na tumhākaṃ.
sn35.101:8.7.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact isn’t yours: give it up.

sn35.101:8.9.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissatī”ti.
sn35.101:8.9.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.”

sn35.102:1.2.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn35.102:1.2.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.102:1.4.eng: The eye isn’t yours: give it up.

sn35.102:1.6.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn35.102:1.6.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.102:1.9.pli: Te vo pahīnā hitāya sukhāya bhavissanti.

sn35.102:1.12.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.

sn35.102:1.15.pli: So vo pahīno hitāya sukhāya bhavissati …pe…

sn35.102:1.16.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi na tumhākaṃ.
sn35.102:1.16.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact isn’t yours: give it up.

sn35.102:1.18.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissati.
sn35.102:1.18.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

sn35.102:1.19.pli: Yampi, bhikkhave, na tumhākaṃ, taṃ pajahatha.

sn35.102:1.20.pli: Taṃ vo pahīnaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissatī”ti.
sn35.102:1.20.eng: Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.”

sn35.103:1.1.pli: “Udako sudaṃ, bhikkhave, rāmaputto evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati:
sn35.103:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, Uddaka son of Rāma used to say:
sn35.103:1.1.comm: Uddaka was the second Brahmanical sage under whom the Bodhisatta practiced before awakening (MN 26:16.1). Another of his enigmatic sayings is found at DN 29:16.8. When the Bodhisatta began his study, he first learned to recite the scriptures, and in these two passages we find examples of what those scriptures were. While no teachings attributed to Uddaka have been found in the Vedic corpus, chapter 23 of the Jain Isibhāsiyāiṁ—a collection of sayings of various sages, including Buddhists and Vedists—is attributed to a certain Rāmaputta, who is likely the same person.

sn35.103:1.2.comm: I have not been able to trace this quote. It is verse, albeit unmetrical. | The initial idaṁ (neuter) is an emphatic particle disconnected from the nouns (masculine). It is an idiom of the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa (eg. 3.6.1.5, 3.7.1.2, 3.8.2.15), where it serves to highlight a dramatic statement or gesture; the text’s opening uses this idiom to announce a transformed or realized self-identity (1.1.1.4: “Hereupon, I enter from untruth to truth!”; 1.1.1.6: “Hereupon, I become he who I am”). Repeated initial pronouns are employed as a rhetorical device in some Vedic verses (eg. Rig Veda 6.65.4–5). | A similar phrasing is employed by Brahmā Sahampati at SN 6.13:5.1, where it emphasizes direct experience. | In early Sanskrit and Pali, jātu usually has the sense “ever” (or perhaps “absolutely” per the commentary’s ekaṁsena; see too Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 2.2.2.20, 14.6.8.1). | Vedagū is not attested in Brahmanical texts, but it is perhaps a contraction of Sanskrit vedapāraga in the sense “one versed in the Vedas” (such as Yājñavalkya, Mahābhārata 1.113.40). Given that Buddhist literature assumes it was a term of the brahmins, the Buddha may have learned it from this very passage.

sn35.103:1.3.eng: Hereupon, ever the conqueror of all!

sn35.103:1.4.comm: The terms “dug” (palikhata = Ardhamāgadhī paḍighāta) and “boil” (gaṇḍa), neither of which are particularly common, are used by Uddaka multiple times in Isibhāsiyāiṁ 23. It is remarkable that, although so few of Uddaka’s teachings are preserved, they share this striking language. Probably these were terms used by Uddaka himself; and perhaps “boil”, like “knowledge master”, was adapted by the Buddha from this passage.

sn35.103:1.5.eng: boil’s root was dug out by me!’
sn35.103:1.5.comm: Gaṇḍamūla (“boil’s root”) is also at Thag 4.10:4.1. | Palikhaṇiṁ is first person aorist. In a characteristic touch of Vedic subtlety, Uddaka conceals the subject of the verse, only revealing that he is speaking of himself with the very final letter of the verse.

sn35.103:1.6.pli: Taṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, udako rāmaputto avedagūyeva samāno ‘vedagūsmī’ti bhāsati, asabbajīyeva samāno ‘sabbajīsmī’ti bhāsati, apalikhataṃyeva gaṇḍamūlaṃ ‘palikhataṃ me gaṇḍamūlan’ti bhāsati.
sn35.103:1.6.eng: Even though Uddaka son of Rāma was no knowledge master, he said ‘I’m a knowledge master.’ Though he was no conqueror of all, he said ‘I’m conqueror of all.’ And though the boil’s root was not dug out, he said ‘I’ve dug out the boil’s root.’
sn35.103:1.6.comm: Isibhāsiyāiṁ 23 has rather a different tenor, as there Uddaka is depicted as lamenting the presence of the boils etc., and determining to practice “knowledge, vision, and good conduct” to bring an end to the beginningless course of transmigration (SN 15.1:1.7 and note). The story of the Bodhisatta’s studentship implies that Uddaka knew he was yet to attain the highest meditation that he taught (MN 26:16.9, etc.).

sn35.103:1.7.pli: Idha kho taṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
sn35.103:1.7.eng: A mendicant might rightly say here:

sn35.103:1.9.eng: Hereupon, ever the conqueror of all!

sn35.103:2.1.eng: And how is someone a knowledge master?

sn35.103:2.2.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti;
sn35.103:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant truly understands the six fields of contact’s origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn35.103:2.3.pli: evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vedagū hoti.
sn35.103:2.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is a knowledge master.

sn35.103:3.1.eng: And how is a mendicant a conqueror of all?

sn35.103:3.2.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto hoti;
sn35.103:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant comes to be freed by not grasping after truly understanding the six fields of contact’s origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn35.103:3.3.pli: evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbajī hoti.
sn35.103:3.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is a conqueror of all.

sn35.103:4.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno apalikhataṃ gaṇḍamūlaṃ palikhataṃ hoti?
sn35.103:4.1.eng: And how has a mendicant dug out the undug boil’s root?

sn35.103:4.2.pli: Gaṇḍoti kho, bhikkhave, imassetaṃ cātumahābhūtikassa kāyassa adhivacanaṃ mātāpettikasambhavassa odanakummāsūpacayassa aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammassa.
sn35.103:4.2.eng: ‘Boil’ is a term for this body made up of the four principal states, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
sn35.103:4.2.comm: Also at AN 9.15:2.1. Elsewhere, “boil” is a term for sensual pleasures (AN 6.23) or for suffering (SN 22.122:1.4).

sn35.103:4.3.eng: ‘Boil’s root’ is a term for craving.

sn35.103:4.4.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno taṇhā pahīnā hoti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā;
sn35.103:4.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant has given up craving, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

sn35.103:4.5.pli: evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno apalikhataṃ gaṇḍamūlaṃ palikhataṃ hoti.
sn35.103:4.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant has dug out the undug boil’s root.

sn35.103:5.1.pli: Udako sudaṃ, bhikkhave, rāmaputto evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati:
sn35.103:5.1.eng: Uddaka son of Rāma used to say:

sn35.103:5.3.eng: Hereupon, ever the conqueror of all!

sn35.103:5.6.pli: Taṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, udako rāmaputto avedagūyeva samāno ‘vedagūsmī’ti bhāsati, asabbajīyeva samāno ‘sabbajīsmī’ti bhāsati; apalikhataṃyeva gaṇḍamūlaṃ ‘palikhataṃ me gaṇḍamūlan’ti bhāsati.
sn35.103:5.6.eng: Even though Uddaka son of Rāma was no knowledge master, he said ‘I’m a knowledge master.’ Though he was no conqueror of all, he said ‘I’m conqueror of all.’ And though the boil’s root was not dug out, he said ‘I’ve dug out the boil’s root.’

sn35.103:5.7.pli: Idha kho taṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
sn35.103:5.7.eng: A mendicant might rightly say here:

sn35.103:5.9.eng: Hereupon, ever the conqueror of all!

sn35.104:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you an exposition of the teaching, an explanation of one who has found sanctuary from the yoke.
sn35.104:1.2.comm: For “sanctuary from the yoke”, see note on SN 7.11:6.2.

sn35.104:1.4.eng: And what is an exposition of the teaching, an explanation of one who has found sanctuary from the yoke?

sn35.104:1.5.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.104:1.5.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.104:1.6.pli: Te tathāgatassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn35.104:1.6.eng: The Realized One has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.

sn35.104:1.7.pli: Tesañca pahānāya akkhāsi yogaṃ, tasmā tathāgato ‘yogakkhemī’ti vuccati …pe…
sn35.104:1.7.eng: He teaches yoking oneself to meditation for giving them up. That’s why the Realized One is called one who has found sanctuary from the yoke. …
sn35.104:1.7.comm: The duality between yoga (“yoke”) as “harness, fetter” and as “commitment to practice” is crucial to this sutta. The Buddha is not teaching nihilism, he is teaching us to “yoke” ourselves to the right cause.

sn35.104:1.8.pli: santi, bhikkhave, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.104:1.8.eng: There are ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.104:1.9.pli: Te tathāgatassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn35.104:1.9.eng: The Realized One has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.

sn35.104:1.10.pli: Tesañca pahānāya akkhāsi yogaṃ, tasmā tathāgato ‘yogakkhemī’ti vuccati.
sn35.104:1.10.eng: He teaches yoking oneself to meditation for giving them up. That’s why the Realized One is called one who has found sanctuary from the yoke.

sn35.104:1.11.eng: This is an exposition of the teaching, an explanation of one who has found sanctuary from the yoke.”

sn35.105:1.1.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati kiṃ upādāya uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhan”ti?
sn35.105:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what, do pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”

sn35.105:2.1.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn35.105:3.1.pli: “Cakkhusmiṃ kho, bhikkhave, sati cakkhuṃ upādāya uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhaṃ …pe…
sn35.105:3.1.eng: “Mendicants, when there’s an eye, because of grasping the eye, pleasure and pain arise in oneself. …

sn35.105:3.2.pli: manasmiṃ sati manaṃ upādāya uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhaṃ.
sn35.105:3.2.eng: When there’s a mind, because of grasping the mind, pleasure and pain arise in oneself.

sn35.105:3.4.eng: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.105:5.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.105:5.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.105:7.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya uppajjeyya ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhan”ti?
sn35.105:7.1.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”

sn35.105:11.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?

sn35.105:13.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya uppajjeyya ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhan”ti?

sn35.105:17.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.105:17.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.105:19.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya uppajjeyya ajjhattaṃ sukhaṃ dukkhan”ti?
sn35.105:19.1.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”

sn35.105:21.1.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati …pe… manasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.105:21.1.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

sn35.105:21.2.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.105:21.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.105:21.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn35.105:21.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn35.106:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the origin and disappearance of suffering.

sn35.106:1.3.eng: And what, mendicants, is the origin of suffering?

sn35.106:1.4.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.106:1.4.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.106:1.5.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.106:1.6.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn35.106:1.7.eng: This is the origin of suffering …

sn35.106:1.8.pli: jivhañca paṭicca rase ca uppajjati jivhāviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.

sn35.106:1.11.pli: Ayaṃ dukkhassa samudayo …pe… manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ.
sn35.106:1.11.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas.

sn35.106:1.12.eng: The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.106:1.13.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.106:1.14.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn35.106:1.15.eng: This is the origin of suffering.

sn35.106:2.1.eng: And what is the disappearance of suffering?

sn35.106:2.2.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.106:2.2.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.106:2.3.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.106:2.4.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn35.106:2.5.eng: When that craving fades away and ceases with nothing left over, grasping ceases.

sn35.106:2.6.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

sn35.106:2.7.eng: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.

sn35.106:2.8.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

sn35.106:2.9.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn35.106:2.10.eng: This is the disappearance of suffering. …

sn35.106:2.11.pli: jivhañca paṭicca rase ca uppajjati jivhāviññāṇaṃ …pe…

sn35.106:2.12.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.106:2.12.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.106:2.13.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.106:2.14.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

sn35.106:2.15.eng: When that craving fades away and ceases with nothing left over, grasping ceases.

sn35.106:2.16.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

sn35.106:2.17.eng: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.

sn35.106:2.18.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

sn35.106:2.19.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn35.106:2.20.eng: This is the disappearance of suffering.”
